title: Football chiefs were warned about dangers of heading leather balls by medics in 1966
text:
New research reinforced the link with heading leather balls and brain injuries

Former players also spoke about their struggles with headaches in the article

A club medic highlighted the potential issue in a magazine after the World Cup

Football authorities were 'warned about the dangers of frequently heading the ball by doctors in 1966'.

It fuels concerns of families of former footballers living with dementia that the game has overlooked the dangers for decades after a landmark report this week reinforced the link with heading leather balls and serious neurological diseases.

New research, funded by the FA and the players' union, was published on Monday and showed that former players are three-and-a-half times more likely to die of dementia than people of the same age range in the general population.

Football chiefs were warned about dangers of heading the ball months after 1966 World Cup

In an article published that year, Dixie Dean spoke about routinely suffering with headaches

Football chiefs, however, were first informed about the problems heading the ball could lead to by club medics just months after England won the World Cup in 1966.

An article entitled 'Danger in heading the ball', in the Football League Review magazine of October 1966, quoted a club medic who said the 'continual jarring of the brain tissue could and does affect players'.

Three of the 11 England players who started the World Cup final against West Germany - Martin Peters, Nobby Stiles and Ray Wilson - were all later diagnosed with dementia.

The article also included detail about how Everton legend Dixie Dean routinely took aspirin to combat crippling headaches he suffered after years of repeatedly heading the ball.

Other players such as former England international Tommy Lawton, whose careed spanned 20 years between the 1920s and 1950s, and Northern Ireland star Derek Dougan, who played in the 50s, 60s and 70s,also spoke of their struggles to shake off headaches.

Records also show that a potential link with brain injuries and heading the ball was made by doctors at least 80 years ago.

Families of former footballers who have been struck down by dementia are demanding immediate support and action after the recent major study.

The research, which followed a previous study that was launched shortly before an inquest in 2002 ruled that former West Brom and England player Jeff Astle had died from an 'industrial disease' caused by repetitive blows to the head, also found a five-fold increase in the risk of Alzheimer's, a four-fold increase in motor meurone disease and a two-fold increase in Parkinson's.

Sportsmail columnist Chris Sutton, whose father Mike - a former professional footballer - is suffering from a degenerative disease caused by repetitive brain trauma, has been vocal in condemning the PFA's lack of work in trying to establish links between dementia and football.

'The confirmation that there is a link between football and dementia brings me no satisfaction,' said Sutton.

'It makes me angry. Angry for people like my dad. This study was rolled out 15 years too late.'
description: Football authorities were 'warned about the dangers of frequently heading the ball by doctors in 1966'. New research showed that former players are three-and-a-half times more likely to die of dementia.
